Linear: O(n · fill²)
Nonlinear: O(k · n · fill²)

Where:
• n = nodes
• fill = fill-in during factorization
• k = Newton iterations (typically 5-20)

Single frequency: O(n · fill²)
F frequencies: O(F · fill²) with pattern reuse

Key: Same sparsity pattern at all frequencies
→ Symbolic factorization done once

With LU reuse (constant dt, linear):
O(n · fill²) + O(T · fill)

Without reuse:
O(T · n · fill²)

Reuse gives huge savings for large T!

Iteration: v^(k+1) = v^(k) - J^(-1) f(v^(k))

Per iteration:
• Evaluate f(v): O(m)
• Build Jacobian J: O(m)
• Factor J: O(n · fill²)
• Solve: O(fill)

Converges quadratically near solution

Can reuse when matrix structure unchanged:

✓ Multiple RHS (same A, different b)
✓ AC sweep (same pattern, different ω)
✓ Transient with constant dt (linear circuit)
✓ Newton iterations (same sparsity pattern)

✗ Changing topology
✗ Variable time step

Instead of fixed small dt:
• Large dt when signals change slowly
• Small dt at fast transitions

Typical savings: 10-100× fewer steps

LTE-based control:
dt_new = dt × (tol/LTE)^(1/(p+1))

Typical breakdown:
• Model evaluation: 40-60%
• Numeric factorization: 20-40%
• Solve (fwd/back sub): 5-15%
• Matrix loading: 5-10%
• Other: 5-10%

Model evaluation often dominates!

For well-optimized SPICE:
• DC: ~O(n^1.5) to O(n^2)
• AC per freq: ~O(n^1.5)
• Transient per step: ~O(n^1.5)

Due to sparse methods + good ordering

✓ Small circuits (< 1000 nodes)
✓ Linear circuits
✓ Short transients
✓ Good matrix ordering
✓ Reusing factorization

For 1000-node linear circuit:
DC < 1s, AC(100) < 10s, Trans(1000) < 1min

✗ Large circuits (> 100k nodes)
✗ Highly nonlinear (many Newton iters)
✗ Long transients with fast dynamics
✗ Poor sparsity/ordering
✗ Variable time step (no reuse)

Full chip (1M nodes): hours to days
